text:
Welcome to How To Cook That i'm Ann Reardon and 
if you're new around here you might not know that

every year we make a gingerbread creation at 
Christmas time 🎄 and this year is no exception,

so we're going to get on to that but before we 
do let me show you some of the ones from previous

years and just take a moment to wish you all my 
wonderful subscribers a very Merry Christmas and

thank you for your support throughout this year 
you guys are fantastic ❤️ Now for this year's

gingerbread creations step one is to print and cut 
out the template and any pieces that say join here

line them up and well you know what to do you guys 
are smart. Step two is to make your dough this is

a really easy recipe all you need to do is mix 
all the ingredients together you can even just

use a wooden spoon if you don't have a mixer for 
that. I'll put all the recipe quantities and the

template on my website howtocookthat.net when it 
comes to the spices they are totally optional they

do not affect the texture of the dough in any way 
so you could leave them out all together you can

add more you can change them up and customize it 
to make your gingerbread taste just how you like

it. Once it's mixed it's really soft so now you 
need to cover the bowl and put it in the fridge

for a few hours to let it firm up a bit. For step 
three you want to roll out the dough between two

sheets of baking paper and then take the top 
one off sprinkle the top with flour and this

is just to stop the template from sticking to the 
dough when you're cutting it out. Add the template

pieces into place and carefully cut around it 
now for some pieces you want to leave a border of

gingerbread around the piece that you've cut out 
and for other ones you want to take it away, let

me just show you the difference of what happens 
when you bake it with and without a border.

If i cut two circles and two number sevens so 
you can see a curved edge and a straight edge

and then for one half i'll take all that spare 
dough away and for the other i'll leave a border

around each piece. Halfway through baking 
you need to re-cut the ones with the border

and you can already see the difference ... the 
ones without the border are rounded and the ones

with the border are flatter and straighter edges 
which is ideal for walls where you need to join

them together. As well as the difference in the 
edges there's also a difference in the spread

you'll see the ones without the border didn't 
spread as much so for any pieces that are joining

to another piece or it's important that they don't 
spread and they keep their exact shape to fit to

something put a border of gingerbread while it's 
baking to keep it in place but to me those rounded

edges they just look prettier and they look nicer 
so if it's anything that's just on display it's

not joining to anything don't leave a border so 
that the gingerbread can spread slightly and round

itself out because it looks nicer 😊 The other 
thing to consider is how thick you roll your dough

i'll show you two different thicknesses here, this 
is the thickness i like for walls or larger pieces

that need structure and this is the thickness i 
like for smaller pieces now obviously that's going

to bake a lot faster than this. When you're baking 
large thick pieces of gingerbread the trick is

to bake it until you think it's done take it out 
of the oven put another tray and baking paper on

top and flip it over and then put it back in the 
oven for another 10 minutes so that underside can

really dry out. Once it is done and it's cooled 
if it's still got a little bit of give in it you

can just put it back into the oven again to dry 
out or you can use this trick that i like to do

which is to spread some compound melted chocolate 
all over the back of the piece just to give it a

little bit of extra strength or you could do 
that if you just like the taste of chocolate

with your gingerbread of course. Step four is 
to decorate that's right it is much easier to

decorate this one flat before you put it together 
take some royal icing and draw an outline around

the outside of your city and pipe a square for 
each window. Now take some of that royal icing

and add a little bit of water just a little bit 
at a time because you can always add more but

you can't take it out. Now if i stir this and then 
take the spoon out you can see that the icing is

slowly melting down into a smooth flat surface and 
that's the consistency that you're looking for.

Then we're going to add that onto the city and 
spread it out right up to the border that we piped

and keep going until the whole thing is covered 
and then i like to just give it a little shake

just to help that icing settle out flat. To fill 
smaller areas like the windows a piping bag or a

plastic bag with the corner cut off makes it 
much easier than using a spoon because it's

quite tricky the smaller it gets the more likely 
you are to make a mess now you want to repeat that

with all your other pieces and one other tip 
you might need is if you want straight lines

don't pipe with the bag touching the gingerbread 
hover it above and then as you move along that

line of icing kind of straightens itself out as it 
falls into place. For all your smaller pieces pipe

the outlines as shown on the template and then 
add some icing to fill it and use a toothpick

or anything small that you've got to spread it out 
into all those tricky little areas. If you're not

confident with your drawing and piping abilities 
place the template on top of the gingerbread piece

and using a sharp craft knife cut along the lines 
on the template pushing through the paper and that

will leave a mark on your gingerbread that you can 
then use to guide you when you pipe the outlines.

For some pieces you'll want to pipe in layers 
so for example with the sheep we want to pipe

a curvy pattern around the edge and then flood 
fill in the middle spreading it all the way to

the edge so it looks a bit like a cloud then 
pipe some more white on top and grab some black

and outline the feet and then pipe a little 
face on top. You should wait until the white

is completely dry i was a bit impatient here so 
you'll see later that black kind of bleeds into

the white a little bit. While i'm making the 
sheep let me thank Big Farm Mobile Harvest for

sponsoring this video, I'll put a link below where 
you can download the game for free. The game is

a farm simulator game where you're in charge and 
you need to harvest your crops and plant new ones

and don't forget to collect your eggs and feed the 
chickens. In December there are presents hidden

all over your farm they're really small but if you 
look for them and find them you get extra rewards

like dog bones you can feed those to your dog, 
let me show you, there you go little doggie.

You can also join a co-op or make your own 
with friends and family so you can do some

tasks together as a team. From time to time they 
run some in-game environmental initiatives like in

September they had little tree saplings that you 
had to get in the game and at the end of September

they then donated enough money to plant 5000 
actual real trees not just in-game trees. I'll

put a link below where you can download Big Farm 
Mobile Harvest for free and start playing today.

Now back to our gingerbread house smash up some 
clear hard-boiled lollies these ones that i've got

came in a bag but if yours didn't put them in a 
bag before you put a hammer on them of course and

then add those crumbs of smashed lollies into the 
spaces on this piece so that it's going to look a

bit like a sunburst ☀️ Make sure you load up each 
section really well because otherwise it'll be too

thin once you've done that pop it into the oven 
and let it melt. Did I mention to put nonstick

baking paper underneath? I don't think i did if 
you don't do that it'll stick to the pan so make

sure you've got non-stick baking paper under it. 
Now if you take it out now it will be smooth or

you can leave it in for a bit longer if you want 
it to bubble and then you'll get these bubbles

in the window part which i like but don't leave it 
too long or it will burn. If you want any parts of

your cookie gold you can't just brush luster dust 
on it like we did with the chocolate balloon dog

because unlike chocolate the luster dust doesn't 
stick to icing let me show you... if i brush some

on it looks good but as soon as i brush it again 
it brushes right off so what we need to do is add

a little bit of vanilla essence to make a liquid 
gold edible paint and then you can just paint

that on wherever you want it. Once all your pieces 
are decorated and ready you need to leave it for

a couple of hours to make sure all that icing is 
fully dry especially on those bigger pieces. While

you're waiting if you need a last minute Christmas 
gift it's not too late to order on Amazon if you

get in quickly they're still guaranteeing delivery 
before Christmas in the US and I think Australia

you'll have to check on the website wherever 
you're based. You could get Dave's novel The Deep

Enders, my cookbook, great easy present ideas 
you can wrap them up and give them to someone

on Christmas day. So once your pieces are 
dry it's time for step 5 assembly ... start

by putting together the light box at the back as 
well as adding room for the lights this also adds

stability to the backdrop so it's a good idea. 
This icing is just royal icing that i've added

a little bit of cocoa powder to for colour because 
i didn't want white between the joins on this one.

Add the backdrop into place and you'll need to 
support that with something behind it until it's

set so i'm just going to use a big jar that it 
can lean on. Then add the strips to each side

these will join the two backdrops to give them 
a bit of stability there but it also means that

there's a gap between them so you've got that 
distance. Put the front backdrop into place now

if you want lights which of course yes we do 
want lights 💡 now is the time to add them into

the light box and just thread the cord through 
and out the back so you can plug that in later.

Lay out your side pieces and pipe the icing along 
the base of where they will go then add the back

of the building and pick up those two side pieces 
and join them together. Near the back but not

quite on it add more icing and add your window 
into place. You will be able to see this inside

section here so neaten up your icing if it's 
bulging out like mine is and make sure it looks

good. Before we do any more of the structure of 
this building we need to add the figures otherwise

it will be too hard to get your hands in. Add a 
little scrap of gingerbread for support and your

little figure in front of it. Once they are all in 
place you can then add the front of the building

and then the roof on top. Now 
you can decorate the roof with

lollies or chocolate or whatever you want but 
i decided to leave mine just plain gingerbread.

Now for the trees you will need a decent amount 
of icing and some extra gingerbread scraps

behind them to keep them upright because they're 
quite top heavy so rest them against something

as they set. Add your little donkey into place and 
your sheep on the other side and then on the front

of the stable add a scrap of gingerbread just 
underneath the awning there and plenty of icing

and pop the star into place now you're either 
going to need to stand there and hold that

to support it until it sets or put something 
underneath it and do the same with your angel.
angels sing glory on high
peace be with you friends on this beautiful night.

wise men bring precious gifts for the 
prince of peace as he sleeps on the hay

who knew that night would hold 
the greatest story ever told

on this holiest of nights we let light into 
our lives this child our guide forevermore

Merry Christmas to all of you, a huge thank 
you to my subscribers and my patrons for

all of your support this year 
you guys are absolute legends I

really appreciate it. God bless make it a 
great week and i'll see you in the new year 💝
